_header: Most sovereign lord O blissful christ Jesu / From our enemies
Note: Cambridge UK, Trinity College R.3.21 (601) (first occurrence), London, British Library Harley 2251, and London, British Library Addit. 34360 [olim Phillipps 9053] have only one stanza of Envoy and alter dedication to Edward IV. Cf. 3200.
Title(s): A Prayer for King Henry VI and his Queen and the People
Subjects: prayers, for the nation; Henry VI; Edward IV; historical poems; envoys
_description: John Lydgate, ‘A Prayer for King Henry VI and his Queen and the People’ — eight stanzas rhyme royal, and an Envoy of four stanzas

BodFair16.First Lines:
Most souereigne lord o blessed crist ihesuffrom oure enemyes
                    delyuer vs and oure foon…
BodFair16.Last Lines:
…And ay preserve vnder thy myghty hondehym and hys moder thy
                    peple and thy londe
BodFair16.Note:
With a variant envoy of four stanzas with refrain: ‘And preserve
                    vnder thy myghty honde / him and his moder thy peple and thy
                    londe’.
BodFair16.Attributed Author:
John lidgat (added in the sixteenth century after ‘Explicit’,
                    f. 200v)
BodFair16.Attributed Title:
Ab inimicis nostris defende nos criste (f.
                    199*v)
BodFair16.Facsimiles:
Norton-Smith,  John. 
             “Introduction.” 
             Bodleian Library MS Fairfax 16.
         London: Scolar Press, 1979.
BodFair16.Editions:
Mahir,  Otto,
                        ed.  
             Eine religiöse Gedichte John Lydgates.
         Oberviechtach: Adolf Mahir, 1910: 44-8.
MacCracken,  Henry Noble,
                        ed.  
             John Lydgate: The Minor Poems, Vol. I: Religious Poems.
EETS
         e.s. 107 (1911; repr. 1961): 212-16.
Robbins,  Rossell Hope,
                        ed.  
             Historical Poems of the XIV and XV Centuries.
         New York: Columbia UP, 1959: 235-9.

CamTCC601.First Lines:
Most souerayn lord O blysfull cryst Ihesuffrom oure enemyes defende
                    vs of oure foonVnder whose grace and vndyr whos vertuWe byn assuryd
                    where so we ryde or goon…
CamTCC601.Last Lines:
…Drede god do law loue trowthe & worthynesAnd dryue thy
                    folke ayene to stedfastnes
CamTCC601.Note:
Second occurrence in MS; ten stanzas, followed by the Envoy of
                    Chaucer’s ‘Lak of Stedfastnesse’ (see 3190).

BLHar2251.First Lines:
Most souerayne lord o blesful crist Ihesuffrom oure enemyes defende
                    vs of oure foon…
BLHar2251.Last Lines:
…holy preserve vndir thy myghti handhym and his moder his
                    peple and his land
BLHar2251.Attributed Title: Ab Inimicis nostris defende nos criste (f. 10v)

BLHar7578.First Lines:
Moost soueraine lord o blessith crist Ihesuffrom oure ennemy
                    deliuere vs and oure foon…
BLHar7578.Last Lines:
…And preserue vnther thy mighty handeHim and his moder the
                    people and thy londe
BLHar7578.Editions:
Wright,  Thomas,  and  James Orchard Halliwell-Phillipps, eds.  
             Reliquiae Antiquae.
         2 vols. London: Smith, 1845: 1.227-9.
Wülker,  Richard Paul,
                        ed.  
             Altenglisches Lesebuch.
         2 vols. in one. Halle: Lippert, 1874, 1880: 2.8-10.

BLAdd34360.First Lines:
[M]Ost souerayne lord o blisful crist Ihesuffrom oure enemyes
                    defende vs of oure foone…
BLAdd34360.Last Lines:
…Holy preserve vndir thi myghti handHym and his moder his
                    people and his land
BLAdd34360.Attributed Title: Ab Inimicus nostris defende nos criste (f. 69)
